bibl.title: Draft of speech and background notes for the dedication of the Camp Lazear Memorial, by Philip Showalter Hench, December 3, 1952

div1.p: In this draft, Hench discusses the Cuban-American cooperation underlying the conquest of yellow fever. He mentions the Havana Yellow Fever Commission of 1879 and the choice of the Finca San Jose as an experimental site because of its yellow fever immunity. He describes Finlay's mosquito hypothesis and experiments, and the initial lack of support for his theory. Finally, Hench outlines the work of Lazear and the Reed Commission, quotes Reed and Finlay, and concludes with praise for both the Cubans and Americans. [See 04435001 and 04435013 for a shorter draft, in Spanish and English, of the speech.]

div1.head: Draft of speech and background notes for the dedication of the Camp Lazear Memorial, by Philip Showalter Hench, December 3, 1952

p.hi:
THE HISTORIC ROLE OF THE FINCA SAN JOSE AND “CAMP LAZEAR” (QUEMADOS DE MARIANAO)
IN THE CONQUEST OF YELLOW FEVER BY CARLOS FINLAY, WALTER REED AND THEIR ASSOCIATES

div1.p:
(To be revised somewhat, condensed markedly, and presented at the
Dedication of “Camp Lazear,” Habana, Cuba, December 3, 1952,) by
Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota

Man is a forward looking creature with a backward looking mind. For in-
spiration to solve the problems of today he often fruitfully turns to the dramatic
events of the past. Thus he may search and wander over the face of the earth until
that exciting moment when he can stop, and with the thrill of rediscovery, exclaim:
“This place - this is the very spot. Here is where it happened!”

But too often he merely marks an “X” on a map and goes on his way. Ladies
and gentlemen, that must not happen here for this is a place of tremendous significance.
And it will not happen here because high officials of your government and distinguished
Cuban physicians have a strong appreciation of spiritual values and of the historic
perspective. Thus they wish the world to remember always that from this ancient Finca
San Jose 52 years ago there was delivered to all the world the confirmation of a
truth - a brilliant truth which changed despair into hope and gave the promise of
life to countless millions.

President Batista, my countrymen are greatly honored and pleased that you and
your countrymen choose to dedicate “Camp Lazear.” In a most gracious and friendly
manner you are uniting forever the honored names of several of my countrymen with
that of your own beloved and eminent humanitarian, Carlos Finlay, and of his associate
Claudio Delgado.

It is fitting that this be done because, individually and collectively,
they worked mightily, all at the risk of life and one at the cost of life, to defeat
a common foe and to serve a common cause. To you, sir, and to others who have done
so much to create this shrine, to Dr. Saladrigas, Dr. Recio, Dr. Nogueira, Dr.
Rodriguez, Dr. Andreu, Dr. Ramos and their associates, my countrymen and I extend
our most sincere thanks.
Page 2 (Havana)

Others have told you of those who discovered and fashioned the truth we
memorialize today. Let me speak also about the place we dedicate today. The very
spot where we gather saw the dramatic climax of an incredible scientific adventure,
of a great human endeavor - the potential destruction of one of man's greatest
enemies - yellow fever, the “saffron horror.”

p.hi: Cuban-American Cooperation Underlying the Conquest of Yellow Fever

div1.p:
The conquest of yellow fever was accomplished as the result of an amazing
cooperative venture between your countrymen and mine, a venture which is still unique
in medical annals. Underlying the individualistic genius and the strong moral courage
of the chief participants were political and scientific statesmanship of a high order.
The central theme which united the hopes and the varied opinions and contributions of
many was a desire to serve mankind, if necessary above and beyond the call of duty.

This drama concerned many characters and scenes but it had one unifying
stage-setting, the Finca San Jose, and three main acts or chapters provided by
(1) the work of the Havana Yellow Fever Commission of 1879, (2) the life-long work
of Carlos Finlay and his associate, Claudio Delgado, and (3) the work of Walter Reed
and his associates of the U. S. Army Commission of 1900.

The unrestricted generosity of the Spanish-speaking peoples is legendary.
You of Cuba uphold that tradition magnificently as I personally have reason to know,
having been for many years the happy recipient of your friendship and kindness.
Your willingness to share what you have is an old attribute. Thus beginning about
1761 and for the next 140 years you graciously permitted my countrymen and others
to export from this fair land a generous amount of yellow fever. Up to a point this
was strictly a matter of “free enterprise,” presumably just a personal, man to man
affair. But being bureaucrats, our customs and other officials eventually chose to
look into the situation.

p.hi: The Havana Yellow Fever Commission of 1879

div1.p:
And so for the first time in its history, the United States Government
established on June 20, 1879, a sanitary expedition, named the Havana Yellow Fever
Commission of the National Board of Health. It was to cooperate with your country-
Page 3 (Havana)
men in studying yellow fever and its purpose was stated precisely: “to serve not one
but all nations.”

The chairman of the American Commission was Dr. Stanford E. Chaille, Prof.
of Physiology and Pathology at the University of Louisiana, New Orleans. Its secretary
was Dr. George Sternberg of the U. S. Army, one of those you are honoring today; he
was one of America's pre-eminent bacteriologists and later became Surgeon General of
the U. S. Army. Another member was the Cuban, Dr. Juan Guiteras, then Prof. of Path-
ology at the University of Pennsylvania, the well-loved physician and teacher who
later returned to Cuba and the University of Havana.

In a fine spirit of international cooperation your Spanish governor-general
Don Ramon Blanco, Marquis of Peña Plata, and many distinguished citizens and physicians
of Cuba, welcomed the American Commission most graciously. Furthermore your govern-
ment established an auxiliary Spanish Commission of twelve eminent Cuban and Spanish
physicians, one of whom was Carlos Finlay. Although Doctor Finlay had already
studied yellow fever intensively for 21 years, this was his first official connection
with sanitary work.

The American Commission set out to discover (among other things) those
places in Cuba, especially in and around Habana, where the incidence of yellow fever
was the highest and the lowest. Soon they were directed to this little town of
Marianao where 6,863 people lived in 666 houses.

p.hi: The Curious Immunity of The Finca San Jose

div1.p:
Senor Alcalde, you will be pleased to know that the American Commission
called Marianao “the cleanest, most attractive and beautiful town in Cuba.” Despite
this its annual mortality rate was high (39.5), almost twice that for the whole
island of Cuba. But they made an interesting discovery: Although yellow fever was
endemic in Quemados and Marianao, one spot here was practically immune - the lovely,
quiet Finca San Jose which had belonged to the distinguished Pedroso family for about
200 years.
Page 4 (Havana)

Because of its salubrious reputation the peaceful Quinta San Jose had been
leased to the Jesuit fathers to whom it was a place of rest and refuge and a place
for the “acclimitization” of newcomers from abroad. So long as the Jesuits remained
at the Finca San Jose (1872-1883) none who remained there ever developed yellow fever
although it was all around them. This intriguing fact was specially noted by the
American Commission. But they found no reason therefor, except that the Quinta was
“on high ground, open, cool and well ventilated by the breezes.”

Thus, way back in 1879, fate, as we can see from the Chaille report, began
to bring together not only the men who were destined to accomplish, or witness closely,
the conquest of yellow fever, but even the very place where the final drama was to
develop more than 20 years later.

p.hi: The Chaille Report, 1879 - Its Influence on Dr. Carlos Finlay

div1.p:
Thanks largely to the help of your countrymen, the Chaille report represents
a historic mile-stone. It masterfully separated fact from legend, truth from super-
stition. Within its 240 crowded pages were assembled more indisputable facts than
were to be found in any previous report. For one brief glittering moment it even
toyed with destiny and flirted with immortality when it spoke of the “aerial pilgrimage”
of the yellow fever poison (P. 128). One could find therein practically everything about
yellow fever, everything that is, except the most important and elusive factor of all
- its cause.

Thus it might be said that the eminent and zealous commissioners were full
of facts but were deprived of that final wisdom whereby they could implement their
encyclopedic knowledge.

Despite its clear exposition of all the known facts, this report of the
Havana Yellow Fever Commission appears not to have altered notably the thinking of
the sanitarians and physicians of my country nor that of 11 of the 12 “Spanish
Commissioners.” But, fortunately for the world, it served its purpose because it
influenced strongly the receptive mind of just one Cuban physician, one of the com-
missioners - Carlos Finlay.
Page 5 (Havana)

p.hi: Dr. Finlay's Mosquito Hypothesis - Its First Phase

div1.p:
For 21 years (1858 - 1879) Dr. Finlay had held, and sometimes expounded,
the belief that yellow fever was somehow related to the alkalinity of the atmosphere
(Finlay's Sel. Works, P. 625). But his association with the American Commission and
its report set his mind in ferment. Pondering the accumulated data on climatic, at-
mospheric and other factors, Dr. Finlay concluded that his own long-held theory was,
in his own words, now “utterly indefensible” and would have to be abandoned and that
he should re-examine the whole situation from a new viewpoint.

Here we can observe the contrasting tenacity and flexibility of Finlay's
mind. The teluric theory engaged his loyalty for 21 years (1858 - 1879), then the
mosquito theory for 19 years (1881 - 1900) prior to its acceptance. Despite his
devotion to the first theory he abandoned it quickly and willingly when faced with
controverting facts, and a superior idea. Now sharing the Chaille Commisson's
opinion that “the poison of yellow fever was a living organism” of unknown nature
and source, Dr. Finlay began patiently to build on this feeble and nebulous fundament
a superstructure which, after years of neglect, was to excite the admiration of the
whole world.

During 1880 he formulated the first phase of his theory. As if guided by
an unerring “divining rod” of his own making, he passed by thousands of bacterial and
insect-possibilities, and, having concluded that the agent must be a winged, blood-
sucking insect indigenous to yellow-fever localities, he chose the culex mosquito as
the likely culprit. Later, with characteristic modesty he spoke of this epoch-making
cerebration as the result of “a simple reasoning,” an example of the magnificent
understatement of a genius.

In December 1880 he began to study the mosquitos collected in his own
house. In 1881 he made his first seven inoculations, pausing in August to present
his memorable first report which was completely ignored. In 1882 he made no inocula-
tions, possibly because, as he stated later, he developed temporarily a doubt as to
whether the culex was the natural transmitter of the disease.

p.hi: Dr. Finlay at the Quinta San Jose, 1883

div1.p:
In 1883, fortified with highly suggestive data on the appropriate effects
(6) (Havana)
of heat, cold and altitude on the culex, (data analogous to that related to the develop-
ment of spontaneous yellow fever), he confidently resumed his inoculations, and here
for the second time the Finca San Jose became closely identified with the medical
triumph we commemorate today. The Jesuit fathers, mentioned above, were still en-
joying the mysterious, unexplained immunity of the Quinta San Jose. What better
place could be found to demonstrate the malevolence of his special mosquitos than one
where, for at least 11 years, no spontaneous yellow fever had developed.

Between July 15 and August 21, 1883, five volunteers (4 Jesuits and one of
their servants) received from Doctor Finlay 8 inoculations over there in the Quinta
San Jose. (Dr. Hench points to the Quinta San Jose.) Among these inoculations was the
one on Padre Urra which, during the next 17 frustrating years, gave Finlay the most
confidence and satisfaction.

Eleven years later, September 1894, Finlay paused to add up the score: it
was not encouraging. He had inoculated 90 persons with results which he himself con-
sidered positive in only 18 per cent; he had written 44 papers on his mosquito hypothesis,
but aside from the faithful Delgado he had acquired not a single known convert. Lesser
men might well have given up. But Dr. Finlay faced the facts squarely. Despite
his disappointment at the unresponsiveness of his medical colleagues he conceived of
a new approach to the problem of preventing yellow fever and proposed new suggestions.
But these too were ignored until they were extended and successfully adopted by Gorgas
7 years later (1901).

Thus, after admitting that his method of therapeutic inoculation constituted
a “troublesome” procedure, one “not likely to gain adherents,” (Select Wks, p. 232)
he suddenly changed pace temporarily and laid down three main indications concerning
the prevention of contact between the appropriate mosquitos on the one hand and in-
fected or susceptible persons on the other hand, measures which were the forerunner
of those used so effectively by Gorgas after 1901.
-7- (Havana)

But this period of discouragement and pessimism was to be his last, and
represented darkness before dawn. The new revalations of 1898 that mosquitos, des-
pised and denounced by him for to long, played a crucial role in the development of
malaria encouraged him greatly. But even these discoveries brought to his related hy-
pothesis no professional converts or governmental support, despite the prophetic, last
conclusion of the Chaille Commission that the poisons of yellow fever and malaria
require for their growth “some conditions which are the same.”

Would the world never accept the truth of his conception? Why did the
medical profession, and the sanitarians of Cuba, the United States and elsewhere,
so universally and unanimously disregard or discount the inductive reasoning and
experimental evidence which seemed so convincing to Finlay. I think his son, Dr.
Charles E. Finlay, has given us the best explanation: (1) Dr. Finlay was far ahead,
too far ahead of his time: in 1880 nothing was known of disease-transmission by
insects, and his work antedated all of the great mosquito-malaria discoveries of Manson,
Ross and others. (2) In making his inoculations Finlay's objective was (according
to his son's book) “not demonstrative” but primarily therapeutic (C. E. Finlay, P 76,
American edition). He was trying less to demonstrate the production of mild experi-
mental yellow fever than to produce an impressive, prolonged post-inoculation im-
munity from severe, possibly fatal spontaneous yellow fever. Thus in his later re-
ports he paid as much, if not more, attention to his long-term results (the duration
of post-inoculation “immunity”) than to his short-term results (the development of
yellow fever soon after inoculation).

In other words in placing the primary emphasis on the accomplishment of his
second, or therapeutic objective, he did not deem it necessary or practicable to
surround the first procedure (the inoculations) with every possible scientific safe-
guard, or to carry them out under rigid conditions of absolute quarantine. To him
the relative isolation of his volunteers before and after inoculation seemed sufficient;
it was certainly more practical and convenient for the inoculees. But because Finlay's
volunteers were not strictly quarantined those few who later developed yellow fever
- 8 - (Havana)
were believed (by every official and physician except Finlay and Delgado) to have
somehow gotten spontaneous yellow fever in the ordinary, unknown way.

From a study of this and other decisions which Dr. Finlay made, we can
judge that whenever a choice concerning patients had to be made he chose to be a
physician first - the considerate therapeutist and humanitarian, a “cold,” impersonal
experimentalist second. Being the gentle, kindly, religious physician that he was,
he could make no other decision. But this admirable attribute brought him years of
neglect, inadequate recognition and the loss of a clear-cut and exclusively personal
victory; I suspect that in the last analysis, after recognition was attained he
considered the price not exorbitant and that, had he had a chance to do it all over
again he might well have made the same hard choices.

p.hi: The Habana Yellow Fever Epidemic of 1900

div1.p:
As the 20th century dawned, Cuba endured two invaders - one new, one old.
The liberating army of Americans, non-immune to yellow fever, was waiting anxiously
to go home; the usual spring invasion of the yellow fever poison was at hand. As
could have been expected, the two “invaders” promptly collided, as if by some devilish
chemotaxis. A new and vicious epidemic of yellow fever resulted. And what of Finlay's
species of mosquitos? Despite his 19 years of accusation they quietly went about
their malicious business, completely unmolested and unsuspected.

Some of the American soldiers from Camp Columbia had private quarters in
Quemados. Yellow fever began to appear a few blocks from where we now are. The
first victim lived at what was then (and still is) 102 Real Street (Calzada Real).
From thence the poison spread, not next door, but around the corner to what was
number 20 General Lee Street (now #404). During May and June 1900 the epidemic
spread rapidly among the non-immunes of Habana and Quemados.

With the U. S. forces were two contract surgeons: one was Dr. Aristides
Agramonte, a Cuban physician experienced in yellow fever research; the other was an
able young physician and laboratory expert, Dr. Jesse Lazear who, unaccustomed to
yellow fever, got busy trying to learn whatever he could about it. On hand to
help with the diagnosis was the “Habana Board of Yellow Fever Experts,” established
- 9 - (Havana)
1899 for that purpose under the chairmanship of Dr. Finlay, other members being
Guiteras, Albertini and Gorgas.

p.hi: The United States Army Yellow Fever Board, 1900

div1.p:
Surgeon General Sternberg in Washington promptly created another com-
mission, the U. S. Army Yellow Fever Board, chiefly because of the emergency affecting
American troups in Cuba but also because it was an opportune time to investigate
the, to him, dubious claims which were being made for the latest “yellow fever germ”
- Senarellis bacillus. Appointed on May 24, 1900 to this Board were Major Walter
Reed and Dr. James Carroll who were in Washington, and Drs. Agramonte and Lazear who
were already at Camp Columbia making clinical, pathologic and laboratory studies on
the yellow fever victims.

It appears that at last Dr. Finlay was about to get his second convert in
the person of Dr. Lazear, for the record (Dr. Lazear's own hand-written laboratory
notebook) shows that on May 23, 33 days before the Army Board had its first meeting
at Camp Columbia (June 25), Lazear captured for his own microscopic inspection
six mosquitos in the room of the yellow fever patient at 20 General Lee Street.

But to the Board as a whole Finlay's mosquito theory was just one of the
theories they planned to investigate. Although one or more representatives of the
Board visited Dr. Finlay late in June and received from him eggs of his culex mosquito
(Finlay's Selected Wks., p. 411) which Lazear proceeded to breed, top priority was
given to the bacterial theory of Sanarelli upon which the Board spent 5 busy but
fruitless weeks as they found no significant germs in the bodily fluids and tissues.
of yellow fever victims.
“Perhaps Dr. Finlay is Right!”

Late in July a curious and crucial observation was made when Agramonte,
then Reed and Lazear went to study an epidemic among Soldiers at Pinar del Rio. A
soldier in a prison cell sickened and died of yellow fever. But his cell mates, ex-
posed to the same food and atmosphere, remained well. Could a winged agent have
entered between the bars of the open window, struck one man down and gone away?
- 10 - (Havana)
Perhaps Dr. Finlay was right after all! Returning to Camp Columbia the Board
promptly made the study of Finlay's mosquitos its chief objective. Another visit
was made to Doctor Finlay who graciously offered whatever help he could give. How
happy he must have been to find at long last physicians so impressed by his ideas
that they determined to test their validity immediately.

But to carry on the work human volunteers were required and the Board
members decided to inoculate each other first. At this juncture Reed, unfortunately,
had to return to Washington (August 2) to finish the important report of a three-man
medical commission of which he had been a member and whose chairman had just died.

p.hi:
Early Experiments at Columbia Barracks Post Hospital - Failures, Then Sudden Success
Death of the Martyr, Dr. Jesse W. Lazear

div1.p:
In August, nine American volunteers, including Dr. Lazear, were inoculated
with presumably “infected mosquitos” but nothing happened. Then suddenly Dr. Lazear
successfully produced experimental yellow fever in Dr. Carroll (August 31) and in
Private William Dean (September 6). Two days later Lazear wrote his wife an exciting
but cryptic letter (September 8). Then a few days later (September 18) he himself de-
veloped the disease (His nurse was Lena Warner whom you honor today.). In a week he
was dead of what, for official purposes, was allowed to be recorded as accidental
yellow fever but which was (according to recently discovered data) almost certainly
secret, self-induced experimental yellow fever.

p.hi: Newly Discovered Crucial Details of the Man-Mosquito Formula

div1.p:
Reed returned hastily to Habana (October 4), deeply depressed by Lazear's
death, elated that success seemed near at hand, but confused by the contrasting nine
negative and three “positive experiments.” Reed studied intently the available
records, especially Lazear's pocket-notebook which the hospital's young commanding
officer, Lieutenant (now General) Truby had carefully protected.

Herein was a key to the age-old mystery; the key was provided by data on a
crucial point which even the genius of Finlay had not clarified precisely and which
Lazear himself may or may not have recognized as he made his fateful notes. The notes
would not have revealed the key to a casual reader. But Reed's clear mind (fortunately
-11- (Havana)
conditioned by the 1898 report of Dr. H. R. Carter on the interval between infecting
and secondary cases of yellow fever) noted the critical differences between the
timings of the successful and unsuccessful inoculations.

Under usual conditions (those present in Quemados that summer) the mosquitos
could only become “infected” if they bit yellow fever patients within the first three
days; thereafter the “poison” disappeared from the patients' peripheral blood. Next
the poison had to “ripen” at least 12 days within the mosquito before the latter's
bite could become harmful.

p.hi: Again The World's Indifference and Ridicule

div1.p:
Reed quickly prepared the Board's preliminary note which he read in
Indianapolis late in October. But the report received little professional support or
public credence. Thus, for example, an editorial in a Washington paper called their
work “silly and nonsensical rigamarole.” (November 2). It was now the Board's turn
to be the recipient of the sort of indifference, skepticism and ridicule which Drs.
Finlay and Delgado had endured for so long. But this is not surprising because these
three inoculations, though “successful,” were relatively uncontrolled, as had been
Finlay's, in that none of the 3 volunteers was under “strict quarantine” (in the
experimental sense) although Private Deen had been confined within the otherwise
fever-free Columbia Post Hospital. The skeptical world was no more receptive to, or
impressed by Reed than it had been by Finlay and so it quite properly demanded more
data with incontrovertible proof.
“Camp Lazear” on the Finca San Jose

And that is what Reed, Carroll, Agramonte and their brave volunteers finally
obtained from the experiments performed here at their experimental station, “Camp
Lazear,” on the Finca San Jose between November 20, 1900 and March, 1901. The money
for this purpose, Cuban money, was wisely allotted to Major Reed by General Leonard
Wood, the provisional Governor General. Did ever an investment of $10,000 pay such
rich dividends!

How did it happen that for the third time (1879, 1883, 1900) the Finca San
Jose became the locale for important observations on yellow fever? The Jesuits sur-
-12- (Havana)
rendered the Finca San Jose in 1884, and by July 1900 its owners, Dr. Ignacio Rojas,
his wife the former Senora Maria Teresa Lomas, viuda de Pedroso, and their family
were permanently occupying the Quinta, but had leased part of the adjacent finca to
Don Antonio Sosa.

After visiting many prospective places for their experimental camp, Major
Reed chose the Finca San Jose. Apparently Dr. Agramonte recommended the place to
him (Scientific Monthly, Dec. 1915). According to the entry of November 15, 1900 in
his diary or day book, Dr. Rojas by agreement with Don Sosa, leased the finca to “the
Military Health officers of the American Army through the mediation of Dr. Echevarria,”
and thereafter received a monthly rental of “$20.00 American gold” from Major Reed or
from his deputy, friend and “right hand man,” Major Kean, Chief Surgeon of the De-
partment of Western Cuba.

Although uniquely appropriate, Reed's felicitous choice of this already-
historic place appears to have been quite coincidental (and Dr. Charles E. Finlay,
who as a youth visited Camp Lazear with his father and Major Reed, told me in 1941 that
he shared this opinion). The previous contacts which Chaille (1879) and Finlay
(1883) had had with the Finca San Jose appear to have escaped the notice of Reed
and his colleagues (or at least of Reed) for they were not mentioned in any of the
Board's official or unofficial writings.
Drama at Camp Lazear: “Buildings Number One and Two”

The specially guarded and quarantined experimental station established on
this spot was named “Camp Lazear” in honor of their martyred colleague. Several
tents were set up right over there (Dr. Hench points). There the soldier-volunteers
lived and slept when they were not otherwise occupied. Then two small specially
constructed wooden buildings of equal size were erected: Building Number One or the
“Infected Clothing and Bedding Building,” and Building Number Two, the “Infected
Mosquito Building.”

This “old warrier” (pointing) constitutes the somewhat reconstructed remains
of Building Number One which had only two small windows and was heated by a small stove
to a tropical temperature. Herein several volunteers (among them Dr. Cooke who died
just one month ago) slept for many nights on foul-smelling pillows and sheets soiled
- 13 - (Havana)
with the blood and vomitus of Las Animas Hospital yellow fever victims; since such
material (“fomites”) had long been regarded as infectious the heroic uninformed
volunteers fully expected to catch yellow fever, but none did, simply because there
were no mosquitos in the building. Thus up the smoke-stack of this little building
went, figuratively and literally, the long-held notion that “infected belongings”
caused the disease, a notion which had cost uncounted millions of dollars, as such
material was needlessly destroyed or fumigated.

Eighty yards in front of Building Number One was Building Number Two;
it stood right over there (pointing) until it was blown down in the tornado of
1926. That building was divided into two parts separated merely by a finely meshed
wire screen.

As Reed, Finlay and others watched from behind the wire screen, John Moran
lay down on a cot on the other side of the room and exposed his body for two 1/2-hour
periods to the bites of 15 infected mosquitos. He promptly developed severe yellow
fever, while other volunteers who stayed long hours on the opposite side of the screen
remained well. You of Habana knew Johnny Moran well, for he lived here among you for
many years as an honored citizen and died here September, 1950. He was my esteemed
friend whom I often visited here.

In the bodies of thirteen more American and Spanish volunteers, who are named
on the bronze tablets, yellow fever was produced at will, either through the medium
of mosquito bites or by injections of infected blood or serum. One of them was James
L. Hanberry, the sole surviving volunteer who is prevented by illness from being your
guest today. Once sick, they were removed immediately from Camp Lazear to a small
yellow fever “hospital” across the La Playa railroad tracks from the old Columbia
Post Hospital. Fortunately, all these brave volunteers survived, thanks to the expert
professional care of Dr. Roger P. Ames (whose widow has come all the way from
North Carolina to be with you today), and to the devoted nursing of Gustav Lambert.

p.hi: Dr. Finlay's Professional Visits to Camp Lazear, 1900-1901

div1.p:
Although Dr. Finlay did none of his own experimental work at Camp Lazear,
he frequently visited this spot, primarily in his capacity as a member of the Habana
- 14 - (Havana)
Yellow Fever Board to confirm the diagnoses of experimental yellow fever, or with his
friends, Major Reed, Dr. Carroll and Dr. Agramonte, to note with delight the final
development of his thesis. Thus he adorned with his presence not only the Quinta San
Jose (1883) but Camp Lazear as well (1900-1901).
Time to Celebrate!

Their problem solved after eight months of work the U. S. Army Board dis-
banded Camp Lazear on March 1, 1901 (but they kept it under lease until October 1901).
Now armed with precise knowledge Gorgas within three months freed Habana of its age-
old pestilence.

Senor Presidente, ladies and gentlemen, I wish that after these memorable
ceremonies we could all go down to the Parque Central of Habana, enter the door of
the narrow building next to (i.e. north of) the old Hotel Inglaterra, and climb the
32 steps to a long narrow room on the second floor above what is now the “Press Wire-
less of Cuba.”

Let us imagine we are doing this tonight and the time is 7 p.m., Saturday,
December 22, 1900. The room, brightly lit, is host to about 60 men for this is Del-
monico's Restaurant, and here are gathered a distinguished company of Cuban and Ameri-
can governmental and medical personalities, including “all the members of the Academy
and of the School of Medicine” (Dominguez, Engl. Tr., p 104). Among them we see
Governor-General Wood who is presiding, the Cuban physicians - Drs. Dominguez, Guiteras,
Tamayo and Presno and the Americans, Reed, Carroll, Agramonte, Gorgas, and Kean.. Tonight these 60 men have all come here to honor Dr. Finlay, to whom
toasts will be drunk in “grand Pouche Romaine au Finlay.”

As Major Reed takes a seat near the guest of honor, two strong emotions
compete within him for ascendency. In his mind is anxiety. Just today a Washington
newspaper once more ridiculed the the work of Reed and his colleagues, calling them
“medical amateurs,” and sarcastically dismissing the mosquito hypothesis as ridiculous
speculation. At her home near Washington, Mrs. Reed will see the uncomplimentary
editorial and, being a loyal wife, she will, in careful privacy, express her annoyance
in firm but ladylike fashion.

However the source of Reed's concern is related, not to the foolish,

pontifical editorialist in Washington, but to the men he left at Camp Lazear an hour
or two ago. Just yesterday that brave Irish lad, 24 year old Johnny Moran, spent 30
more minutes with the infected mosquitos in Building Number Two. He may well develop
yellow fever two or three days from now. Let's see, that might be on Christmas Day.
If so, what a wonderful Christmas gift Johnny would be giving to all the world! And
eleven more young volunteers are waiting their turn to match their physical and
spiritual courage against death by yellow fever.

Yes, the Major has ample reason for concern: the planned experiments are
by no means finished; it may take three more months to obtain enough proof to satisfy
the more critical scientists. But in Reed's heart is a humble joy, a thankfulness
impossible to suppress. His gratitude is properly directed to many, to “my colleagues
Drs. Carroll and Agramonte,” to Kissinger, Moran, Hanberry, “Cookie” and the rest
of the volunteers (“Gentlemen, I salute you”) but especially to three others:-

To the young martyr, Jesse Lazear “He was a splendid, brave fellow, and
I lament his loss more than words can tell; but his death was not in vain. His name will live in the history
of those who have benefited humanity...It is my own earnest wish that whatever credit
may be hereafter given to the work of the American Commission in Cuba during the
past year, the name of my late colleague, Dr. Lazear, may be always associated
therewith.”

To his mentor Dr. Finlay: “We here desire to express our sincere thanks to
Doctor Finlay who accorded us a most courteous interview, and has gladly placed at
our disposal his several publications relating to yellow fever during the past 19
years; and also for the ova of the species of mosquito with which he had made his
several inoculations....To Dr. Finlay must be given full credit for the theory of
the propagation of yellow fever by means of the mosquito....”

To his Maker: “I thank God...the prayer that has been mine for 20 or
more years that I might be permitted in some way or sometime to do something to
alleviate human suffering, has been answered.”

Answered, too, is the 20 year old prayer of the honored guest, Dr. Finlay.
The banquet is now ending and he has just been given a bronze statuette, a small
token of esteem, a fine souvenir of this wonderful evening.

It is almost midnight. Listen quietly as Doctor Finlay responds briefly,
graciously, feelingly: “Twenty years ago, guided by indications which I deemed
certain, I sallied forth into an arid and unknown field; I discovered therein a
stone, rough in appearance; I picked it up and with the assistance of my efficient
and faithful co-laborer, Dr. Claudio Delgado, polished and examined it carefully,
arriving at the conclusion that we had discovered a rough diamond. But nobody would
believe us, till years later there arrived a commission, composed of intelligent men,
experts in the required kind of work, who in a short time extracted from the rough
shell the stone to whose brilliancy none can now be blind.” (Carlos Finlay, Dec. 22,
1900).

As Dr. Finlay sat down, the applause began. It has never ceased: 52 years
later it still continues, as our presence here today testifies.

Of the 25 principal men whose hopes were fulfilled at Camp Lazear, three
were Cubans (Drs. Finlay, Delgado, Agramonte), four were Spaniards, one was English,
one was Irish and 16 were Americans. Some were humbly born; some reached high estate;
some were civilians, others were soldiers, professionals and volunteers; some were
catholic, some were protestant, some were Hebrews. And here on this hemisphere's
23rd parallel they demonstrated well the potential brotherhood of man.
